publicationStmt.publisher: Die Schriftkultur des christlichen Äthiopiens und Eritreas: Eine multimediale Forschungsumgebung / Beta maṣāḥǝft

licence.p: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0.

msContents.summary: I-1) Homily by the Orthodox on St John the Baptist (fols. 43r-44v, possibly fragments of two different texts from the same Ms.), hand a (28 lines) II) Homilies (fols. 45r-122v), hand b (identical to hand e of UM-045) (25 lines) II-1) Possibly the Homily by Jacob for the third Sunday in Lent (fols. 45r-59ra) (cp. Orient. 8192, 5.) II-2) Homily on Lent, for the third Sunday in Lent (fols. 59rb-66vb) (cp. Orient. 8192, 6.) II-3) Homily by John Chrysostom for the fourth Sunday in Lent (fols. 66vb-69ra) (cp. Orient. 8192, 7.) II-4) Homily by the Orthodox on Lent, for the fourth Sunday in Lent (69ra-73ra) (cp. Orient. 8192, 8.) II-5) Homily by Gregory of Antioch for the fifth Sunday in Lent (fols. 73ra-79ra) (cp. Orient. 8192, 9.) II-6) Homily for the Friday of the sixth week in Lent (fols. 79ra-84vb) (Orient. 8192, 10.; beginning in the same way, without title) II-7) Homily for the Saturday of the sixth week in Lent (fols. 73ra-85vb) (cp. Orient. 8192, 11.) II-8) Homily by Jacob (ʾabba Yāʿqob) for the Sunday of the sixth week in Lent (fols. 85vb-91ra) (Orient. 8192, 12.) II-9) Homily by the Orthodox for Palm Sunday (fols. 91ra-97ra) (cp. Orient. 8192, 13.) II-10) Homily by ʾabbā ʾEfrem for reading at the service on Holy Thursday (fols. 97ra-103vb) (cp. Orient. 8192, 14.) III) Martyrdom of St George of Lydda (fols. 98rv, 142r-148v), hand c (27-28 lines) (identical to hand d of UM-045) (cp. E.A.W. BUDGE, The History of George of Lydda, the patron Saint of England, London 1930, respectively pp. 89 l.17-91 l. 4 and pp. 96 l. 12-108 l. 18) II-11) Homily by ʾabbā ʾEfrem for reading at the service on Holy Thursday (fols. 97ra-103vb) (cp. Orient. 8192, 14) II-12) Homily by ʾabbā ʾEfrem for Easter Eve (fols. 103vb-107vb) (cp. Orient. 8192, 15., beginning in the same way), in full II-13) Homily by the Orthodox for Easter Sunday (fols. 107vb-118va) (cp. Orient. 8192, 16.), in full II-14) Homily on the Suffering of Jesus Christ for Monday in Easter-week (fols. 118vb-122va, fol. 122 is loose), incomplete (cp. Orient. 8192, 17.) I-2) Text containing God’s promises to Israel (fol. 123rv, a loose leaf), hand a (27 lines in a column) IV-1) Homily by Cyril (Gerlos) Patriarch of Jerusalem on the Resurrection of Jesus Christ (fol. 124r-131v, after the incipit page, the biggest part possibly missing), hand d (25 lines) IV-2) Discourse by John Chrysostom on the life and decollation of John the Baptist (fols. 126r-132v), possibly almost complete, hand d V-1) A homily for Easter (fol. 133rv), ancient hand e VI-1) 2 Kings (fol. 134rv), ancient hand f (similar but not identical with hand a of UM-045) IV-3) Maṣḥafa lәdäta la-Māryām “Book of the Nativity of Mary” (fols. 135, 136va-141v), end missing, hand d (Cp. M. CHAINE, Apocrypha de Beata Maria Virgine, Romae 1909 [CSCO 39, 40 (SAe 22, 23)], “Liber nativitatis Mariae”; the correct sequence is fols. 136va-141v, 135) IV-4) Martyrdom of Theocritus the Reader, commemorated on 17 Maggābit (fol. 136r-va), end part and explicit, hand d VII-1) Text concerning ʾabbā Yoḥannǝs (?) (fol. 149rv): hand g (28 lines) VIII-1) The Finding of the Holy Cross by St Helena (?) (fols. 150r-152r, explicit), hand h (35 lines) V-2) Unidentified homily (fol. 152rv), ancient hand e (31 lines) IX-1) 2 Kings 18:32-19:15 (fol. 153rv), ancient hand j (35 lines) (identical to the hand of UM-058, the text follows on UM-058 fol. 66rv) I-3) Text concerning the Nativity of John the Baptist (fol. 154rv), hand a (28 lines) I-4) Prayer concerning Yoḥannǝs (Maṭmǝq) (?) (fol. 155rv): hand a (?) (27 lines) V-3) Homily by John Chrysostom on Easter Sunday (fols. 156ra-161ra), in full (?), ancient hand e (32 lines) (cp. BerPrKult orient. fol. 3075 no. 17, HamSixBerl 1, 298-99) V-4) Homily by an anonymous author on Easter (fols. 161ra-161vb), 16th-cent. hand k; the text is written in empty space after Text V-3, and may be the beginning of the following text (which had been acephalous, originally or though the loss of leaves) V-5) Unidentified homily (fols. 162r-167v), acephalos (but cp. above), ancient hand e (31 lines) X) Text concerning Archangel Michael, the Vision of Daniel and the Three Holy Children (fol. 168r-169v), hand l (28 lines) V-6) Unidentified homily (fols. 171r-177v), end part and explicit, ancient hand e (31 lines) V-7) A homily of Jacob (of Sarug?) (fol. 177vb), heading only, ancient hand e V-8) Unidentified homily (fols. 172ra-173ra), explicit, ancient hand e V-8) Homily by John Chrysostom on penance (fols. 173ra-185v), ancient hand e (cp. BerPrKult orient. fol. 3075 no. 25, HamSixBerl 1, 300) I-2) Text concerning John the Baptist (fols. 186r-187v): hand a (28 lines) V-9) Unidentified homily (fols. 188ra-189rb), end part and explicit, ancient hand e (31 lines) V-10) Homily by Jacob of Serug on the Apostle Thomas (fols. 189r-194v), in full (?), ancient hand e (cp. EAE III, 262b) V-11) Homily by John Chrysostom on Lazarus (fols. 194va-197rb), in full (?), ancient hand e (cp. BerPrKult orient. fol. 3075 no. 20, HamSixBerl 1, 299; cp. EAE III, 293b) V-12) Homily by John Chrysostom on the Samaritan woman (cp. BerPrKult orient. fol. 3075 no. 21, HamSixBerl 1, 299; Orient. 774 fols. 126r-131r, EAE III, 293b), in full (?), ancient hand e V-13) Homily by John Theologus (Tewologos) on Easter Sunday (fols. 205vb-211vb), end and some fols. missing, ancient hand e (cp. Orient. 774, no. 22).

supportDesc.condition: ff. 1-42 (fragment of a Four Gospels manuscript) are described as Ms. UM-50a. The fragment of ten manuscripts (43-203) are loosely placed into the binding of UM-050a.

projectDesc.p: Encoded according to TEI P5 Guidelines.

revisionDesc.change: transformed from mycore to TEI P5
